posts.name: James Lyon
posts.cooked: How do you detect if a coral is in your robot? It looks like it’s pretty important both for driver assist and due to the fact that you can load from the coral stations during auto. Just curious about your solutions (I’m going to steal them).

posts.name: Chris Cross
posts.cooked: There are many ways to detect an object (Coral in this case).  We are going with two beam break sensors.  The first one will tell the motor to slow down.  When the second one is tripped, the motor will slow down even further.  Then, when the first beam break is back to “normal” after the Coral has passed it, the motor will stop, and the Coral should be in the correct position to be delivered.  That’s the theory. This could also be achieved with two switches or prox sensors as well.

posts.name: Eddie
posts.cooked: In my experience i would recommend installing a series of Beam Breaks to detect coral, I have found them to be the easiest to code and most reliable.

posts.name: Matt Dicks
posts.cooked: We are using a CanRange in the middle of our outtake to detect if the coral has passed it then run it backward a small amount so it is safely in our outtake for scoring.
We’re using a Time of Flight sensor to detect if we have coral. A beam break would work too since that’s basically how we’re using the ToF.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Sensors for my intake Sensors

Photoelectric wiring question Technical Discussion

We are using an array of near sighted optical sensors, held about 0.125" to 0.25" from the coral.

They just “see” bright objects, works great on coral. Carpet dust and whatnot hasn’t impacted things yet (will probably pack a can of compressed air for the pit)

https://www.digikey.com/en/products/detail/tt-electronics-optek-technology/OPB716Z/1015170?s=N4IgTCBcDaIPYAcBGB2AjANgF4gLoF8g

This specific part number will just plug into the RIO and be read like any generic DIO. (You may need a pullup resistor for Arduino projects and the like)

We chose these over a beam break because our mechanism can’t guarantee alignment of the beam. ToF sensors could have worked here too in theory, but are overkill in our application.

link_counts.title: OPB716Z TT Electronics/Optek Technology | Sensors, Transducers | DigiKey

posts.cooked: We are using motor current. If it is above 25 amps for 10 robot cycles we have a coral or something stuck in our motor.
